pullRequest.body:
feat(CategoryTheory/Monoidal): Cat, the category of categories, is monoidal with the cartesian product of categories

Co-authored-by : atopaz@fastmail.com
Co-authored-by : yael.dillies@gmail.com


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [e55f50d0fd](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15258/commits/e55f50d0fd9b18c0ce92d728904d133098a98ad0)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.ChosenFiniteProducts.Cat`|547|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ associator_hom`
`+ associator_inv`
`+ chosenTerminalIsTerminal`
`+ instance : ChosenFiniteProducts Cat`
`+ isLimitProdCone`
`+ leftUnitor_hom`
`+ leftUnitor_inv`
`+ prodCone`
`+ rightUnitor_hom`
`+ rightUnitor_inv`
`+ tensorHom`
`+ tensorObj`
`+ tensorUnit`
`+ whiskerLeft`
`+ whiskerLeft_fst`
`+ whiskerLeft_snd`
`+ whiskerRight`
`+ whiskerRight_fst`
`+ whiskerRight_snd`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

Maybe this should all live in a new file `CategoryTheory/ChosenFiniteProducts/Cat.lean` as an analogue to the file `FunctorCategory.lean` in that folder. Since you're defining a monoidal category structure, you might want to provide some API lemmas for it, `leftUnitor_hom_app`Â etc. Look at the `FunctorCategory`Â file for inspiration.
According to Morisson, register these lemmas as simp would interfere with `coherence` tactic so I removed the attribute
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by dagurtomas.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10469532261/job/28992768015)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10469532261/job/28992768472)
There are lots of extra spaces. I suggested removing all that I found, but please go over everything carefully again and make sure it's properly formatted.

```suggestion
/-- The chosen terminal object in `Cat`. -/
abbrev OneCat : Cat.{v, u} := Cat.of (ULift (ULiftHom (Discrete Unit)))

/-- The chosen terminal object in `Cat` is terminal. -/
def isTerminalPUnit : IsTerminal OneCat :=
  IsTerminal.ofUniqueHom (fun _ â†¦ (Functor.const _).obj âŸ¨âŸ¨âŸ¨âŸ©âŸ©âŸ©) fun _ _ â†¦ rfl

```
This is to make everything universe-polymorphic (i.e. make it work for `Cat.{v, u}`).

Thank you, how to manage universe properly is still a bit of a mystery to me for now.
 
And it is apparently big pb for code reuse. 

(In Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Functor/KanExtension/Basic.lean
`The bicategory API cannot be used directly here because it would not allow the universe
polymorphism which is necessary for some applications.`)

I should read more about this

```suggestion
/-- The product cone in `Cat` is indeed a product. -/
def isLimitProdCone (X Y : Cat.{v,u}) : IsLimit (prodCone X Y) := BinaryFan.isLimitMk
  (fun S => S.fst.prod' S.snd) (fun _ => rfl) (fun _ => rfl) (fun _ _ h1 h2 =>
    Functor.hext
      (fun _ â†¦ Prod.ext (by simp [â† h1]) (by simp [â† h2]))
      (fun _ _ _ â†¦ by dsimp; rw [â† h1, â† h2]; rfl))
```

You don't need both the `def`Â and the `instance`. Since you can get this is by `inferInstance`, you should in general not state it as an instance explicitly, but you could state it as an `example` for future readers of the file, to show that this instance exists.

Similarly below.

These lemmas should have names corresponding just to the LHS. So for example `leftUnitor_hom`Â instead of `leftUnitor_is_snd`. This file roughly follows the same structure as the one about functor categories, and you can follow the same naming as that file does.

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
# Chosen finite products in `Cat` 

This file proves that the cartesian product of a pair of categories agrees with the 
product in `Cat`, and provides the associated `ChosenFiniteProducts` instance.

```
Here (in the whole first part), you can also follow the naming scheme in the `FunctorCategory`Â file

You should be able to use the `â—`/`â–·` notation (type it using `\lhd`/`\rhd`). 

I think it's better to split this up into two simp lemmas, `whiskerLeft_fst` and `whiskerLeft_snd` which say what happens when you postcompose with the `fst`/`snd` projections. Similarly for `whiskerRight`. 

Could you also add the lemmas for `tensorHom`, `associator`, etc.?
since they all hold (I think..) by `rfl`, is the goal to register those as `simp` ?
Yes, exactly

Although now that I think about it, maybe they're bad simp lemmas. Equality of functors is generally an "evil" notion (not in this case, since it's definitional equality). In any case, we should have the lemmas, but maybe not as global simp lemmas. I suspect at least in some cases you'd want them as simp lemmas, and then you could just turn on the simp attribute locally.

You should ask for more opinions about this on Zulip.

```suggestion
lemma tensorObj (C : Cat) (D : Cat) : C âŠ— D = Cat.of (C Ã— D)  := rfl
```

```suggestion
lemma whiskerLeft (X : Cat) {A : Cat} {B : Cat} (f : A âŸ¶ B) :
    X â— f = (ðŸ­ X).prod f := rfl
```

```suggestion
lemma whiskerLeft_fst (X : Cat) {A : Cat} {B : Cat} (f : A âŸ¶ B) :
    (X â— f) â‹™ Prod.fst _ _ = Prod.fst _ _ := rfl
```

```suggestion
lemma whiskerLeft_snd (X : Cat) {A : Cat} {B : Cat} (f : A âŸ¶ B) :
    (X â— f) â‹™ Prod.snd _ _ = Prod.snd _ _ â‹™ f := rfl
```

```suggestion
lemma whiskerRight {A : Cat} {B : Cat} (f : A âŸ¶ B)  (X : Cat) :
    f â–·  X  = f.prod (ðŸ­ X) := rfl
```

```suggestion
lemma whiskerRight_fst {A : Cat} {B : Cat} (f : A âŸ¶ B)  (X : Cat) :
    (f â–· X) â‹™ Prod.fst _ _  = Prod.fst _ _ â‹™ f := rfl

lemma whiskerRight_snd {A : Cat} {B : Cat} (f : A âŸ¶ B)  (X : Cat) :
    (f â–· X) â‹™ Prod.snd _ _  = Prod.snd _ _ := rfl
```

```suggestion
lemma tensorHom {A : Cat} {B : Cat} (f : A âŸ¶ B)  {X : Cat} {Y : Cat} (g : X âŸ¶ Y) :
    f âŠ— g = f.prod g := rfl

lemma tensorUnit : ðŸ™_ Cat = Cat.chosenTerminal := rfl
```

```suggestion
lemma associator_hom (X : Cat )(Y : Cat )(Z : Cat ) :
    (associator X Y Z).hom = Functor.prod' (Prod.fst (X Ã— Y) Z â‹™ Prod.fst X Y )
      ((Functor.prod' ((Prod.fst (X Ã— Y) Z â‹™ Prod.snd X Y))
      (Prod.snd (X Ã— Y) Z :(X Ã— Y) Ã— Z â¥¤ Z))) := rfl
```

```suggestion
lemma associator_inv (X : Cat )(Y : Cat )(Z : Cat ) :
    (associator X Y Z).inv = Functor.prod' (Functor.prod' (Prod.fst X (Y Ã— Z) : X Ã— (Y Ã— Z) â¥¤ X)
      (Prod.snd X (Y Ã— Z) â‹™ Prod.fst Y Z)) (Prod.snd X (Y Ã— Z) â‹™ Prod.snd Y Z) := rfl

lemma leftUnitor_hom (C : Cat) : (Î»_ C).hom = Prod.snd _ _  := rfl

lemma leftUnitor_inv (C : Cat) : (Î»_ C).inv = Prod.sectr âŸ¨âŸ¨âŸ¨âŸ©âŸ©âŸ© _  := rfl

lemma rightUnitor_hom (C : Cat) : (Ï_ C).hom = Prod.fst _ _  := rfl

lemma rightUnitor_inv (C : Cat) : (Ï_ C).inv = Prod.sectl _ âŸ¨âŸ¨âŸ¨âŸ©âŸ©âŸ©  := rfl
```

```suggestion

end CategoryTheory.Monoidal
```

Could you fix the whitespace? (There are many other instances to fix.)
```suggestion
lemma tensorHom {A : Cat} {B : Cat} (f : A âŸ¶ B) {X : Cat} {Y : Cat} (g : X âŸ¶ Y) :
```
I think I fixed them all. is there a linter somewhere for this ?
What is this supposed to communicate to the reader?
This example should be removed.

I don't these `example`'s are well-motivated. If the goal is to make sure this doesn't disappear, then they should be tests. If the goal is to communicate to the reader that they can be solved by typeclass synthesis, this should be a comment.

I think I suggested putting this as an `example` (the author had written it as an `instance` initially). My idea was communication to the reader, is there a rule to not use examples for this? (I'm certainly guilty of a few such `example`s in the library)

There is no policy per se. I think the module doc string is a better place to explain how these instances allow Lean to synthesize a `MonoidalCategory` instance for `Cat`. At the least, there should be a comment before the `example`s to explain what these are supposed to convey and why they are here.
I will add a comment, it is clearer.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(CategoryTheory/Monoidal): `Cat` is monoidal with the cartesian product of categories
